data.title: Tenaris signals stable Q4 sales, targets 20–25% EBITDA margin amid shifting tariffs and resilient North America demand
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Tenaris S.A. (TS) Q3 2025

Management View

  • Paolo Rocca, Chairman & CEO, emphasized Tenaris's continued industrial and commercial strength, stating, “Our results in third quarter once again highlight the unique industrial and commercial position. We have built around the world with competitive differentiation in key markets as well as an efficient industrial performance.” He outlined stable sales in North America despite slowed drilling activity, attributing this to the strength of the customer portfolio and operational efficiency. Rocca highlighted record production at mills in Bay City, Hickman, and Sault Ste. Marie, with 90% of U.S. OCTG sales produced domestically.
  • Rocca described ongoing expansion in Canada, referencing a new service yard in British Columbia and increased production at Sault Ste. Marie to support Montney shale and LNG export projects.
  • On the offshore front, Rocca noted a growing order backlog for projects like TPAO Sakarya in the Black Sea, with “deliveries from the middle of next year as we look forward to the confirmation of other major offshore process FID.”
  • Rocca discussed improved investment conditions in Argentina post-election, increased energy production with a new 95-megawatt wind farm, and full power self-sufficiency at Campana operations.
  • Carlos Gomez Alzaga, Chief Financial Officer, reported, “Our third quarter sales reached $3 billion, up 2% year-on-year, but down 3% sequentially, mainly reflecting lower sales to the North Sea and lower shipments for offshore line pipe projects in the Middle East, partially offset by a resilient level of sales to our rig direct customers in the U.S. and Canada.” He noted EBITDA of $753 million, which included a $34 million one-off gain, with a margin of 25%.
  • The Board approved an interim dividend of $0.29 per share, a 7% increase compared to last year.

Outlook

  • Management expects Q4 sales to be “close or in line with the third quarter,” with Rocca stating, “we also expect for the next quarter to have a level of sales close or in line with the third quarter.”
  • EBITDA is projected to be lower, with a “range of single digit because of the impact of the tariff in our cost of sales,” as Rocca explained. The company expects margins to remain “in the range between 20% and 25%, not far slightly lower than the one we had in the third quarter.”
  • Rocca signaled potential changes to U.S. steel tariffs in 2026, mentioning ongoing negotiations and possible reductions.
  • COO Gabriel Podskubka noted, “the Middle East, stable and resilient into next year,” with a strong pipeline business offsetting lower OCTG in Saudi Arabia and a constructive view on offshore activity into 2026.

Financial Results

  • Q3 sales reached $3 billion, EBITDA was $753 million (including a $34 million gain), and free cash flow was $133 million after capital expenditures and share buybacks.
  • Net cash position ended at $3.5 billion after share buybacks totaling $351 million.
  • Interim dividend per share was raised to $0.29. The quarter included a one-off $34 million gain from the return of U.S. antidumping deposits.
  • Capital expenditure was $185 million, and operating cash flow was $318 million.

Q&A

  • Arun Jayaram, JPMorgan, asked about the impact of Argentina’s elections and Q4 margin trends. Rocca responded, highlighting improved financing and investor sentiment in Argentina post-election, expecting increased investment and gradual rig count growth. On margins, Rocca noted ongoing inventory pressure and anticipated “the impact of this situation and the level of price will start to recover.” Guillermo Moreno, President of U.S.A., added that inventories remain high but imports should decrease further, balancing the market.
  • Matthew Smith, BofA Securities, inquired about sales mix and shareholder distributions. Rocca linked strong welded sales to U.S. product substitution and pipeline deliveries, expecting the mix to revert in Q4. On buybacks, Rocca stated, “we will execute the second tranche of the buyback… it will be up to the Board to decide what to do once we completed this second buyback.”
  • Marc Bianchi, TD Cowen, questioned the impact of tariffs on EBITDA. Rocca clarified that adjusted EBITDA (excluding one-offs) will be lower due to tariffs, estimating a $40 million increase in cost of sales. CFO Alzaga confirmed incremental tariff effects next quarter.
  • Alessandro Pozzi, Mediobanca, asked about Q1 2026 and Middle East tenders. Rocca cited possible tariff reductions via negotiations and described increased domestic production as a mitigating factor. Podskubka described the Middle East as stable, with potential rig rebound in 2026 and continued pipeline activity.
  • Sebastian Erskine, Rothschild & Co Redburn, discussed Mexico’s outlook. Rocca pointed to gradual drilling increases, improved PEMEX payment, and private sector activity, expecting more volume over time.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts’ tone was neutral to slightly cautious, probing on tariffs, margins, and regional demand. Questions focused on sustainability of sales, margin impacts from tariffs, and regional growth trends.
  • Management maintained a confident but measured tone, emphasizing resilience and adaptation to tariffs, with Rocca stating, “Tenaris continues to demonstrate the resilience of its operation and financial performance.” Slight defensiveness appeared in margin discussions and tariff impacts, but long-term confidence was consistent.
  • Relative to the previous quarter, both analysts and management maintained a similar tone, with ongoing focus on tariffs and regional demand drivers.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Q3 sales were $3 billion, down from $3.1 billion in Q2. EBITDA increased sequentially to $753 million (including a one-off gain).
  • Margins remained strong, with a 25% EBITDA margin in Q3 versus close to 24% in Q2.
  • Free cash flow declined from $538 million in Q2 to $133 million in Q3, reflecting increased capital expenditures and share buybacks.
  • Net cash position decreased from $3.7 billion to $3.5 billion.
  • Management reaffirmed guidance for sales and margins near current levels, with added caution on tariff-driven cost impacts in Q4 and 2026.
  • Analysts’ questions remained focused on tariffs, regional performance, and shareholder returns. Management’s tone was steady, with ongoing confidence but heightened attention to cost management and inventory.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management repeatedly cited high U.S. and Canada tariffs as a key cost challenge, expecting further impact in Q4. Rocca estimated, “today, we are paying every quarter an amount in the range of $150 million this tariff.”
  • Elevated inventories in North America were linked to price pressure, with Moreno noting inventories at about seven months of consumption and expecting reductions as imports decrease.
  • Delayed PEMEX payments contributed to higher working capital; Rocca expects improvement in Q4.
  • Market uncertainties include potential changes in U.S. steel tariffs and ongoing trade negotiations, as well as fluctuating regional demand dynamics.

Final Takeaway

Tenaris management conveyed that, despite ongoing headwinds from tariffs and inventory levels, the company expects stable sales and margins in Q4, with a resilient North America business, constructive outlook for offshore and Middle East markets, and improving conditions in Argentina and Mexico. The company continues to prioritize operational efficiency, regional adaptability, and shareholder returns, while closely monitoring tariff negotiations and cost management for 2026 and beyond.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Trump-Putin summit canceled after Moscow sends memo to Washington - FT
data.description:
The United States cancelled a planned Budapest summit between President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin following Russia's firm stance on hardline demands regarding Ukraine, the Financial Times reported on Friday.

The decision came after a tense call between the two countries' top diplomats, the report said.

Plans for a summit in Budapest this month between the two leaders were put on hold after Moscow stuck to demands, including that Ukraine cede more territory as a condition for a ceasefire.

Days after Trump and Putin had agreed to meet in the Hungarian capital to discuss how to end Russia's war in Ukraine, the Russian foreign ministry sent a memo to Washington underlining the same demands to address what Putin calls the “root causes” of his invasion, which include territorial concessions, a steep reduction of Ukraine’s armed forces, and guarantees it will never join NATO, the newspaper reported.

The development comes as Russia successfully tested two nuclear-powered weapons - the Burevestnik cruise missile on Oct. 21 and the Poseidon super torpedo on Oct. 28. It also conducted nuclear launch drills on Oct. 22.

Trump has, meanwhile, directed the Pentagon to resume testing nuclear weapons after a 33-year pause.

data.title: Kesko Oyj reports Q3 results
data.description:
• Kesko Oyj press release (KKOYF): Q3 group net sales in July-September totaled €3,227.3 million (€3,026.6 million).
  • Comparable earnings per share €0.36 (€0.34); reported earnings per share €0.35 (€0.35).
  • Reported net sales grew by 6.6%, while comparable net sales grew by 3.5%.
  • Operating profit totalled €204.0 million (€202.1 million).
  • Cash flow from operating activities totalled €287.7 million (€285.6 million).

data.title: Asia mixed: Tech fuels record tallies in Japan and Korea, China slumps on weak factory data
data.description:
Asia stocks presented a mixed picture on Friday, reflecting divergent economic trends across the region. Japanese and South Korean shares continued their strong performance, extending recent record rallies driven by sustained gains in the technology sector. In contrast, Chinese shares faced selling pressure and moved lower. This decline followed the release of weak official factory activity data.

Gold prices fell to around $4,000 per ounce on Friday, set for a second straight weekly loss, pressured by fading expectations of Federal Reserve rate cuts and a US-China trade deal.

Japan (NKY:IND) rose 1.84% to around 52,200, while the broader Topix Index rose 1% to 3,335 on Friday, with Japanese stocks hitting fresh record highs amid a strong rally in technology shares. The Japanese yen hovered near nine-month lows around 154 per dollar on Friday and was on track for a sharp 4% monthly decline, pressured by the election of Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi.

Japan's economic data for September 2025 delivered a mixed picture. The industrial production, which unexpectedly rose by 2.2% month-over-month in September, according to flash data, beating the market expectation of a 1.5% increase and marked a strong rebound from the 1.5% drop recorded in August.

In contrast, retail sales offered a weaker-than-expected performance, rising by just 0.5% year-on-year in September.

The labor market showed signs of slackening, with the unemployment rate holding steady at 2.6% in September, unchanged from August. The number of unemployed individuals increased by 20 thousand, reaching a 14-month high of 1.81 million. 

Recent data also showed Tokyo’s core inflation rose more than expected in October, complicating the domestic policy outlook. 

China (SHCOMP) fell 0.68% to below 3,980, while the Shenzhen Component dipped 0.05% to 13,525 on Friday, extending losses from the previous session as disappointing manufacturing data weighed on sentiment, and the offshore yuan held its decline around 7.11 per dollar on Friday as investors weighed disappointing PMI data and the outcomes from the recent Trump-Xi meeting. 

The NBS Manufacturing PMI plummeted to 49.0 in October 2025, a sharp decline from September’s reading of 49.8, below the market forecast of 49.6 but also marked the lowest level since April. The NBS Non-Manufacturing PMI stood at 50.1 in October, barely budging from September’s 10-month low of 50.0. 

China has allocated 200 billion yuan (USD 28 billion) in local government special bond quotas to support investment in certain provinces, a spokesperson for the National Development and Reform Commission, Li Chao, said on Friday, as reported by Reuters. 

Hong Kong (HSI) fell 0.96% to 26,078 in early trade on Friday, retreating for the third consecutive session as most sectors declined. 

India (SENSEX) fell 0.34% to 84,184 in a choppy morning session on Friday, extending losses for a second straight session, mainly weighed down by declines in metals, banks, and financial services. 

Australia (AS51) fell 0.04% rose 0.4% to around 8,920 on Friday, snapping its three-session losing streak, buoyed by gains in gold stocks and miners on higher commodity prices. 

Australia's Final Demand Producer Price Index ((PPI)) rose by 1.0% quarter-on-quarter in Q3 2025. This rate accelerated notably from the 0.7% increase recorded in the prior quarter, and easily topped market forecasts of a 0.8% rise.

Separate data showed, Australia’s private sector credit rose 0.6% month-on-month in September 2025, matching the pace of the previous month but exceeding market expectations of a 0.5% increase. 

In the U.S. on Thursday, all three major indexes ended lower overnight after disappointing big tech earnings, and after Fed Chair Powell signaled that a December cut “is not a foregone conclusion” after a second rate reduction this year.

U.S. stock futures advanced on Friday after upbeat quarterly results from major tech firms: Dow +0.09%; S&P 500 +0.66%; Nasdaq +1.18%.

Currencies: (JPY:USD), (CNY:USD), (AUD:USD), (INR:USD), (HKD:USD), (NZD:USD).

More on Asia:

Australia Q3 producer inflation hits one-year high, rises by 1.0% Q/Q

Japan's mixed September: Factory output soars, retail sales & labor lag

Bank of Japan holds rates steady at 0.5% as expected, boosts growth forecast

China's Q3 GDP 4.8% Y/Y, hits slowest pace since 2024, but beats quarterly expectations

data.title: Earnings Snapshot: First Solar posts record Q3 volumes but trims guidance
Japan's mixed September: Factory output soars, retail sales & labor lag
data.description:
Japan's economic data for September 2025 delivered a mixed picture, with a surge in factory output counterbalanced by disappointing retail sales and a slight uptick in the jobless rate.

The industrial production, which unexpectedly rose by 2.2% month-over-month in September, according to flash data, beating the market expectation of a 1.5% increase and marked a strong rebound from the 1.5% drop recorded in August.

The rise was the first increase since June and the fastest pace since February, driven by a recovery across several key industries.

In contrast, retail sales offered a weaker-than-expected performance, rising by just 0.5% year-on-year in September, representing a rebound from August's downwardly revised 0.9% decline, it fell short of market expectations for a 0.7% increase, suggesting consumer demand remains tepid.

The labor market showed signs of slackening, with the unemployment rate holding steady at 2.6% in September, unchanged from August. This figure was slightly above market expectations of 2.5% and remained the highest reading since July 2024.

The number of unemployed individuals increased by 20 thousand, reaching a 14-month high of 1.81 million. However, total employment did rise by 24 thousand to a four-month peak of 68.34 million, indicating some underlying strength despite the expanding labor force.

Recent data also showed Tokyo’s core inflation rose more than expected in October, complicating the domestic policy outlook. 

The Nikkei 225 Index jumped 1.7% to around 52,200, while the broader Topix Index rose 1% to 3,335 on Friday, with Japanese stocks hitting fresh record highs amid a strong rally in technology shares. The Japanese yen hovered near nine-month lows around 154 per dollar on Friday and was on track for a sharp 4% monthly decline, pressured by the election of Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi.

More on Japan

  • BoJ minutes reveal ongoing caution on economy amid inflation & market risks
  • Japan's manufacturing PMI revised upward to 48.7 in April
  • Japan to spend ¥388 billion on relief measures for U.S. tariff impact
  • Japan services sector expands for sixth month, but jobless rate hits 13-month high

  • Takaichi elected LDP Chief, poised to become Japan’s first female prime minister

data.title: Newmark Group arranges $600M financing
data.description:
• Newmark Group (NMRK) arranged a $600 million total loan package on behalf of West Shore, with proceeds supporting the refinancing of more than $250 million in existing debt across five stabilized properties.
  • The closing marks West Shore's second SASB transaction in the past 12 months, exemplifying the firm's continued growth among the most active multifamily owners in the Sunbelt region.

data.title: Viking Acquisition prices $200M IPO at $10 per share
data.description:
• Viking Acquisition (VACI) priced its initial public offering of 20M units at $10.00 per unit.
  • The units are expected to be listed on the NYSE and trade under the ticker symbol "VACI.U" beginning on October 31, 2025.
  • Each unit consists of one ordinary share and one-third of one redeemable warrant, with each whole warrant exercisable to purchase one Class A ordinary share at a price of $11.50 per share.
  • The underwriters have been granted a 45-day option to purchase up to an additional 3M units.
  • The offering is expected to close on November 3, 2025.

data.title: Australia Q3 producer inflation hits one-year high, rises by 1.0% Q/Q
data.description:
Australia's Final Demand Producer Price Index ((PPI)) rose by 1.0% quarter-on-quarter in Q3 2025. This rate accelerated notably from the 0.7% increase recorded in the prior quarter, and easily topped market forecasts of a 0.8% rise.

It marked the 21st consecutive quarter of producer inflation and the fastest pace since Q3 2024, with sustained demand in the residential property sector identified as a key contributor to the accelerated growth.

On an annual basis, producer prices also ticked higher. The PPI increased by 3.5% over the year to Q3, a slight acceleration from the 3.4% gain seen in Q2. The Q2 figure had represented the softest annual increase since the third quarter of 2021.

Separate data showed, Australia’s private sector credit rose 0.6% month-on-month in September 2025, matching the pace of the previous month but exceeding market expectations of a 0.5% increase. 

The S&P/ASX 200 Index rose 0.4% to around 8,920 on Friday, snapping its three-session losing streak, buoyed by gains in gold stocks and miners on higher commodity prices. 

ETFs: (NYSEARCA:EWA), (NYSEARCA:FXA), (NYSEARCA:FLAU).

More on Australia

  • Australia's Q2 producer price index rises 0.7%, following soft consumer inflation report

  • Australia CPI slowest in four years in Q2, headline CPI at 0.7% Q/Q and 2.1% Y/Y

  • Australia's trade surplus narrows to five-year low in May, missing forecasts amid export dip

  • Australia's Q1 GDP misses estimates amid weak public spending, consumer demand, and exports

  • RBA Minutes: Rate cut signals caution, data to drive future policy

data.title: China's economic slowdown deepens as factory activity hits six-month low to 49.0 in October
data.description:
China's economic momentum continued to weaken in October, marked by a significant drop in factory activity that fell short of analyst expectations, according to the latest official purchasing managers' index data from the National Bureau of Statistics.

The NBS Manufacturing PMI plummeted to 49.0 in October 2025, a sharp decline from September’s reading of 49.8, below the market forecast of 49.6 but also marked the lowest level since April, highlighting persistent challenges facing the nation's industrial sector. A PMI reading below 50 indicates contraction, reinforcing concerns over the health of the economy.

The NBS Non-Manufacturing PMI stood at 50.1 in October, barely budging from September’s 10-month low of 50.0. This reading suggests that activity in services and construction remains fragile, offering little counterbalance to the manufacturing slump.

The NBS Composite PMI Output Index—slipped to 50.0 in October, down from 50.6 in the preceding month. This critical reading, which includes both manufacturing and non-manufacturing activity, marks a severe slowdown and the lowest level since December 2022.

On Friday, the Shanghai Composite fell 0.2% to below 3,980, while the Shenzhen Component dipped 0.05% to 13,525 on Friday, extending losses from the previous session as disappointing manufacturing data weighed on sentiment, and the offshore yuan 

ETFs: (NYSEARCA:FXI), (NYSEARCA:KWEB), (NYSEARCA:CQQQ), (NASDAQ:MCHI), (NYSEARCA:ASHR), (NYSEARCA:YINN), (NYSE:TDF), (NYSEARCA:CHIQ), (NYSEARCA:GXC), (NYSEARCA:EWH), (NYSEARCA:KBA), (NYSEARCA:YANG), (NASDAQ:CXSE), (NYSE:CAF), (NYSEARCA:CWEB), (NASDAQ:PGJ), (NYSEARCA:KURE).

Currency: (CNY:USD)
